p: In addition to these studies pointing to VBD emergence as proximally a consequence of landscape level dynamics several others have specifically drawn on principles developed in landscape ecology. This ecology subdiscipline is particularly relevant to understanding VDB transmission dynamics thus control. Continually changing land use mosaics viewed at the scale of human interaction (typically hectares or multiple square kilometers in the case of pastoralist movements), including varying physical structure and processes involving abiotic and biotic components, is the central focus of the field of landscape ecology [ 90]. A number of researchers have explored the role of landscape change in relation to VBD transmission or risk [ 91– 93], including most notably Pavlovsky [ 94] who coined the term landscape epidemiology much earlier. Development of this idea thus did not have the benefit of SESR. Though Bradley’s [ 91] description of ‘chronotones’ closely aligns with the cyclic, dynamic nature of changing vector habitats.
